text: SENTRY TOWER - SENTRY 8 ‘ The fifteen foot sentry tower is @ little more than ae covered platform with an armed - always armed - uniformed sentry. Searchlight. Telephone. Around the SENTRY'S neck is a pair of bincculars. He looks off, reacts.
The convoy approaches through monotonous, desolate pine woods.

immediately blows his whistle. This is taken up by others. Over comes gutteral German commands. FROM tOwER - THE CONVOY 11 grinds through the barbed gate and begins forming up in the vast, desolate camp area. 300 yards by 300 yards. Dirt. Surrounded by nine foot barbed wire double fences. Impossible to scale. Machine-gunned sentry towers every 150 yards. Fifteen new barrack huts. Hundreds of guarcs, "ferrets" (Prison spies) converge on the twenty trucks -~ all heavily armed.

The canvas flap is opened and the POW's begin to get out. All tired. Dressed in haphazard uniforms. Carrying pots, pans, dedrolls, boxes; one hes a guitar, another a teapot; some carry nothing; all are RAF officers. They stare arourd silently, appalled by the extent of security rescrictions. .

More ferrets and guards get the ‘silent. POW's into some semblance of order and line them up to be searched. The first man, EAMES - a young Fiight Lieutenant - stumbles, drops his pack, sourly bends down to pick it up.
as he passes a pair of wire cutters to the next in jane. The wire cutters disappear. oe

straightens and allows KRAMER, a German ferret, to search him. Very efficiently. Kramer finds a jack knife, pockets it happiiy. As he nods for Eames to move out... = , CLOSE SHOT. - ‘HANDS 16 the wire cutters are deftly passed over once more - disaypear. .
grinds through and the heavily armed guards close the evil barbed wire gate with finality.
and interrperse the remaining credits over:
The ferrets searching... officers streaming off to find quarters...
Tiny cubicle rooms - leng corridors... officers tapping walls... peering under bunks... into attic traps... settling bedding straight... casing the joint actively. and passively...
a Polish RAF officer, chunky, squats on the dirt near the "trip wire" with WILLIE DIX, a young Englishman.
near the trip wire is HILTS, a taut American. He wears a baseball mitt and stares out of the camp thoughtfully. Beside him is GOFF, another American flyer.
a tall, impeccably dressed American, is thoughtfully watching the German truck driver tinkering. with the engine.
DaI NIMMO 23 a small, dark Welshman, is getting his bunk shipshape in the cursing, shoving mass of men. Nearby is CAVENDISH, a strong tall man with a Flamboyant moustache.

His age is insharp contrast to the others. He steeples his hands thoughtfully, watching some pathetic Russian slave laborers tidy the remains of cut-down trees. His hands are strangely twisted, two fingers almost frozen into a perpetual V for victory sign.
An Australian contemplates.pots.and. pans. Then exits.
strolls along with ERIC ASHLEY-PITT, Lt. Commander RN, Fleet Air Arm. As they walk, they scrutinize the camp. Concerned.

A tough professional soldier - STRACHWITZ - escorts GROUP CAPTAIN RAMSEY past the sentries at the gate. Ramsey is erect, dressed in battered RAF uniform, a scarf at his neck; he limps and walks with a stick. Strachwitz leads him to the Headquarters Building just outside the compound proper.
Strachwitz walks up the steps with Ramsey.
is small, very neat, very efficient. He watches from a window then turns as Strachwitz enters, salutes. THE CREDITS END.
Der Herr Staffel-Kapitaen Ramsey. ©

Good morning, Group Captain. I am Captain Posen, Colonel Von Luger's adjutant. Since, as Senior British Officer, you are to be liaison between the prisoners.eand the Colonel, he wishes to make clear to you certain matters of. -- | (groping) -- the word is 'policy'? i
Ramsey nods politely and Posen turns, Imocks on the door.
Herein.
holds the door open courteously for Ramsey and Posen.

is a Prussian Luftwaffe officer. Colonel. Immaculate. Many medal ribbons. Some from World War One. Of an age with Ramsey. He stands near a window. Big desk - peerless. Von Luger returns Ramsey's casual salute punctiliously.

I am Colonel Von Luger, the Commandant, : (politely) Please sit down. Strachwitz stands stiff at attention. Ramsey sits. Posen stands. Von Luger sits behind the desk. On it as a large file. He passes cigarettes. A long silence.
In the past four years the Reich has been forced to spend an enormous amount of time, energy man power and equipment hunting down escaping officer POW's.
(politely) It's rather nice to know you're “wanted, isn't it, Colonel Von Luger? . .
With us it is not a matter for levity. There will be no escapes from this camp.

(wearily) It is-.the sworn duty of officers to try to escape. If they can't, - it is their sworn duty to cause : the enemy to use an inordinate number of soldiers to guard them and their sworn duty to harass the enemy to the best of their ability.
I know. The men under your authority have been most successful. (CONTINUED)
a
He glances at the file - a photo and a sheet catches his eye - picks it up.

(irritably) . Merivale, for example. Caught at Dunkirk. Escaped. Recaptured. Escaped. Recaptured. He even tried to jump out of the train coming here. Seventeen attempted escapes - this is close to insanity.
Quite.
He was in the First World War -- and he's not even an Air Force Officer.
He's a major in the British Expeditionary Force. As you said. Captured at Dunkirk. - (quizzically) Colonel, do you expect officers to forget their duty? (CONTINUED)

It is because we expect the orposite that we have brought you here. This camp embodies all we have learned of security measures. We have in effect put all our rotten eggs in one basket and -- believe me, Group Captain -- we intend to watch this basket carefully.
(after pause) Very wise.

You will not be denied the usual facilities. Sports, a library, a camp theatre. And for gardening, we will entrust you - during the day - with tools. But please -- (a sardonic grin) -- use them for gardening. Devote | your energies to these things. Give ur your hopeless attempts to escape and with intelligent cooperation - we may all sit out the war as comfortably as possible. There is a moment's pause as, he waits for some response from Ramsey, then -- : ° . aren . |
(continuing) Are there any questions?
Have you ever been caged, Colonel - Von Luger? They stare at each other.
are near the warning wire under the watchful eyes of the sentries and goonbox men. Danny picks up some dirt, lets the sandy soil dribble through his fingers, shakes his head. ( CONTINUED)
CO Too much sand. Willie is studying the woods beyond the fence.
How far are the trees?
Over a hundred feet.
(does some mental triangulation) Less.
Still a long way to dig.
We'll get Cavendish tc make a survey. They stroll along.
Oo I wish "Big X" were here. As I'm. senior tunnel expert, I'm" afraid I might be elected.
You'd make a good "Big X", Willie.
(shakes his head) No. That takes a- different sort of mind.
(looks about to see if he could possibly be overheard) Do you think "Big X" got away?
No. He'd've sent us word, somehow, if he had.
You think the Gestapo has him?
O That - or he's dead.

stand huddled under guard in a group near the Vorlager, morose and dirty. Some wear long Russian Army greatcoais, but most are barely clothed in motley rags. Some carry tools - axes, pitchforks. Some are still finishing their job, tossing branches into the trucks. Merivale joins a group of POW's nearby. Sedgwick, the lanky Australian, is among them.
(urgently) Hold these for me in case I should return. The FOU's react immediately, cover him as he takes off his hat and other identifying clothes, gives them to the men, who pat them on.
(whispers ) Now if you would just put on some sort of brief show for the goons.
What'll it be - "Battle Royal"? "The Mad Prisoner"? "The Busker"? "Fisticuffs"?
Fisticuffs would be jolly ‘good. - Sedgviick grabs Merivaie's sweater from HAYNES, the man holding it.
It's mine, you bloody Limey!

(shouting) no -It's mine you bloody, illiterate | Aussie son of a... | Sedgwick heuls off a haymaker and they go at it. Haynes lands an apparently smashing blow on Sedgwick who goes down. Haynes leaps on him and they struggle - other POW's egg them on excitedly. Guards and ferrets com. over to break ur the fight.
slips in with the Russians, quickly dirties his hands and face.
is lyinz on his face still being pummelled by Haynes, who refuses to be dragged off by the guards. Sedgwick notes Merivale's- strategy with interest.
During all this, IVES, the jockey-sized New Zealander, vaults into the back of the first truck and disappears into the branches.
dive into the next truck, disappear under a camouflage ef branches.

Hendley arrives at one of the trucks, Snakes open a tool box, whisks out a small wrench and pliers. A Ferret spots him. Hendley quickly moves away. He is joined by Ashley-Pitt and Sandy MacDonald. He immediately switches the tools to MacDonald who hides them on his person while WERNER rushes up. Werner is a Ferret. While not stupid, neither is he overly bright. The demands on manpower in Germany pre- cluded elways having brains and efficiency at the level of a sry in a prison camp.
You steal some tools from the truck?
Tools?
Why are you loafing here? Is there a law?
Oh, American,
Yes, and you are a German.
Of course. (CONTINUED)
“C) He immediately begins to search Hendley, patting him \ , all over. He speaks in his earnest way.
(continuing) Why do you come to Germany? Why fight for England - your enemy?
(keeping his attention) Enemy? What do you mean?
In.1812 they burned your capitol. ‘HENDLEY What? Propaganda! Werner is through with him -- turns to MacDonald, but Ashley-Pitt places himself first and Werner begins Searching him.

” (continuing) —_ . Nothing but propaganda, thet's all. ' WERNER . (shaking his head; steadfastly reiterating) It's in the history books. I read it. As Werner searches Ashley-Pitt the latter laughs, can't stand to be searched, he's so ticklish.
(putting. on an act) Oh, I-say. Please! I can't bear it. I'm very ticklish. Under ccver of this MacDonald siips tools to Hendley who gets them into his trousers rocket.
(searching MacDonald) For stealing tools, cooler.
What tools?

stands contemplating the. area between the wire and the fences, and their relation to the goon towers. He is oblivious to the uproar of the fight which is now diminishing. His preoccupied slapping of the baseball in his first baseman's mitt stops. GOFF, another American joins him.
~ Only one other Yank in the place as far as I can find out. Seems like we're new boys. ‘ (beat) Hey, you in some kind of trance or something?
We got us a blind spot.
Huh?
‘The way those goon towérs are Placed, there's a blind spot on that fence.
You're crazy.
(CONTINUED)

Hilts looks off intc nothing for some moments, his eyes glazing as he thinks. Then he snaps out of his reverie, nods his head briskly. First glancing about to see who is watching, he flips the baseball in the air a time or two, then pretending to fumble; deliberately shoves the ball to the place at the fence. No one notices this. Except Goff:
(appalled) You ain't going out there!
Not till the Goons're looking somewhere else. AT RUSSIAN GROUP ‘ 40 Merivale taps a man in front of him.

Tovarich. The man turns. Merivaie holds up two cigarettes, Pantomimes he will trade cigarettes for the axe the man is carrying, and the coat he is wearing. The exchange takes piace. A German guard suddenly shouts an order. Merivale stiffens, then as the men march off realizes that was the command. As the Russians move along the pass the far corner of a hut. Sedgwick pops from behind the corner, falls in behind Merivale. He too has messed himself up and with his gaunt face 41 looks perhaps more convincing than Merivale.
as they march along.
(whispering) You know any Russian?
Cniy one phrase.
Well, come on!
Ya vass lublu.
Ya vass -- ? (CONTINUED)
Lublu,.
(practicing) Ya vass lublu. Ya vass lublu. (then) What's it mean?
I love you.
(reacts, then sourly) What good is that?
I-couldn't say. Hadn't planned on using it myself.
all eyes are attracted to the marching Russians and the purp gun guards marching with them. Ramsey is entering the compound, stands near Hendley, watching.

Hilts notices the attention paid to the marching Russians He takes a deep breath and; as Goff watches in. horror, steps over the warning wire, saunters out to the ball. At the fence he stands motionless for a moment. . The sentries are watching the Russians. It is apparent the goonbo: men don't see him, and he indicates this with a gesture to Goff. Then reaches down for his ball to start back. At this moment, the ferret, FRICK, spots him, yells. There is a burst of fire from a nearby. sentry, the bullets splattering around Hilts' feet as he dives out into the clear area between the warning wire and the fence.

(yelling) Nicht shasen:! Don't shoot: Hold it: He holds his arms high above his head, rockstill. Every gun in sight is fined on Hilts though firing is held. Even the marching Russians and their guards halt as all watch. Frick runs to the edge of the warning wire, shouts at Hilts. (CONTINUED )
You fool: To cross the wire is death.
Huh?
This wire. The warning wire. It 41s absolutely forbidden to cross it. You know that! Hilts holds up the basebell.
My baseball rolled over. How “else could I get it?
You first ask permission. Hilts turns to a goon box machine gunner, holds up the ball.
Hey! Okay?
(furious) Stop this nonsense and get over the wire or you will be killed - instantly.
Okay - okay. The Russians are ordered on the march again. Goff stares at Hilts as if he has burst into flames.

(slapping the ball, winks, studying the fence) Useful piece of information. 44 NEAR THE GATE - STRACHWITZ 4a watches the approaching Russians. As the guards open the main gate for the Russians and they are going through he calls out. Halt! STRACHWITZ t! (CONTINUED)
ay 14. CONTINUED : 4a As the group is halted, Strachwitz walks over to them. Steps directly beside Sedgwick.
Step out? Merivale turns ‘to him,
Nyet. Nyet. (slapping Sedgwick on the shoulder) Tovarich! Tovarich!
So?
Tovarich:
And vho vouches for you, Major Merivale? He gestures to the guards who move forward.

Back in the camp. Next time you go to the cooler. : (to the guards) Bringzen die sofort ins't lage! As Merivale and Sedgwick are escorted back to the compoun the Russians are marched on out. Strachwitz takes a pitch fork from them. The trucks carrying the branches approach the gate. As the first truck stops at the gate Strachwits gets on to it, gently prods the branches. There is a Sudden yell. Strachwitz relaxes sardonically.
Take it easy. He emerges from the branches.
Your name?
(as he gets down) Flight Lt. Ives. (CONTINUED)

Ives immediately gives a short - double whistie through his teeth which is a signal “the jig is up" end the others emerge from the. trucks somewha sheepishly. Then:

I will take no action against you now. This is the first day here and there has been much stupidity - and carelessness. His eyes fall on Frick and the other ferrets near him, who shrivel. ia , STRACHWITZ oS (continuing) ! . on both sides. Dismiss. 45. aT TRUCK De , 45 during all of this, Hilts has sneaked to a truck, where he now hangs spread-eagled underneath by his hands and toes hooked into the lower chassis.

turns away from Ives and the others as they exit and goes grimly to the truck under which Hilts is hanging. He orders the driver out with a gesture.and takes his place at the wheel. Then throwing the truck in reverse, backs into the camp, then slams it into gear and races into the tree trunk studded appell area. The others watch in horror as Strachwitz drives the truck across the stumps. Hilts flattens himself upward to his utmost as the stumps go by him by fractions of an inch. But he doesn't let go or ery out. Strachwitz stops the truck for a moment. Underneath the truck, Hilts' face is grim, but he doesn't budge. Strachwitz's face flushes with anger and slamming the truck in gear again he takes off, this time violently careening the truck over the highest stumps. Finally he stops; beaten in his attempt O to make Hilts give in. He gets out and stands by the tr
He gives Strachwitz a loud derisive ‘bird'.
reacts, n-ves Ives out of the corner of his eyes, but concentrates on the truck.

You may come out now, Hilts! Hilts emerges and faces Strachwitz, his eyes cold with hatred as ferrets and guards converge. Hilts lifts up the tab of the collar of his shirt. Under it (as was often done by Americans in combat) is his insignia of rank.
it's Captain Hilts.
(barking) Cooler! Hilts turms away, under guard, recovers his baseball mitt and bell from Goff and heads off toward the cooler. Strachwitz turns to Ives. Points at him.

Cooler. . ‘Ives goes off after Hilts followed by two sentries. The others watch Strachwitz cautiously. Strachwitz looks them over balefully. Merivale, who has observed ali this with professional interest, moves to Goff.
Who is that chap?
Virgil Hilts, from Nebraska The Cooler King.
I beg your pardon?
(after a pause) In our last camp, Virgil logged more time in the cooler than all the rest put together.
NEAR COOLER - HILTS AND IVES 4g march forward under guard into the cooler.”
Detention cells lead off the long corridor. Barred tiny door windows.

as he enters the tiny cement cell. The door slams shut. Footsteps, another cell door clangs shut as Ives too is put into solitary. Hilts jumps, catches his fingers-on the ledge of the high single small barred window, and chins himself up for a look. Then he drops to the floor again, where he paces about furiously. Finally to cool himself off, he stretches out on the floor where he methodically begins doing push-ups.
Stands near a hut. With him are Danny, Willie, Ashley-Pit Merivale and Sedgwick. The Camp is quiet. Hendlev arrives, passes the tools he has stolen to Sedgwick.
Add these to your collection. . _ MACDONALD . -  (aimost to himself) Quite a first twenty minutes, ZI must say.
I'd say we made fools of ourselves. -
Danny, watching Strachwitz, speaks in his soft, intense , voice,
As the Coerfeldwebel said, this is only the first day.
He sure plans to separate the men from the boys.

A STASF CAR oe 53 approaches the Headquarters Building. KUHN, a high ranking Gestapo civilian gets out of the front seat. He is soft spoken, polite, dangerous. Two SS guards - Kuhn's constant body guard - get out of the back seat with a man in battered RAF uniform between them. This is SQUADRON LEADER CYRIL BARTLETT - a big blonde man with broad shoulders and cold intense eyes. He is handcuffed. Kuhn leads the way to the Headquarters Building.
MacDonald, Hendley and the others watch.
(softly) Eric.
Yes. I'll tell Ramsey. He exits. MacDonald speaks quitely to the other men.
. Let's not tip who it is to the “goons. Pass the word. They move away in apparent disinterest.
comes out nervously to greet Kuhn.
Guten morgen, Herr Kuhn. He exchanges salutes - also with the SS men - sees Bartlett, reacts.
Er ist Bartlett, nicht wahr? Ich habe gehort das er...
You might as well speak English. He understands German perfectiy. Where is Von Luger? (CONTINUED)

With increasing nervousness, Posen leads the way. Obseqicusiy holds the door open for them. Bartiett is shoved into the building.

tiredly puts his foot on a stool in the tiny room, studies great lists of typewritten names. There is Only one bunk in the room which would normally house four. - Rough furniture. Teapot and cup. An excited knock and Ashley-Pitt hurries in.
(breathing hard from running) Excuse me, sir. Some of the chars think they spotted Cyril being taken into HQ.
(then quickly) Better take precautions.
Wheat? We have, sir.

(exits) Yes sir.

(to Posen, snaps) Make a note of Herr Kuhn's "suggestion". looks at the key. Posen unlocks the handcuffs.
Ja, Herr Colonel.
(softly) ‘We have reason to believe he : . is the leader of numerous criminal escape attempts.

(gently) if he falls into our hands once more, he will not be s0 Tucky.
hard) Escaped Air Force officers are the responsibility. of the Luftwaffe, not the Gestapo. (CONTINUED)

waits anxiously. A imock.

Hello, sir.
Hello, Cyril. (CONTINUED )
O) Between them there is enormous camarderie, enormous NO respect. But held right down.
Looks like you've had a rough time.
The Gestapo wanted to find out who helped me to the border. God! I had only a hundred yards to go.
_ (after pause) The fellows wanted to put up a welcome committee, That's for later. Lot of your old. friends here,

i (locks around the camp) How long have you been here? a . . RAMSEY Arrived today. New camp. Expert guards. The elite. He turns back to the teapot, pours. From time to time he glances perturbed at Bartlett who sits staring into space lost in thought.
Here. (CONTINUED)
(drinking) My God, that's good. That's so good. (beat) Christ! We'll never get out of these bloody. camps.
(after pause) Last of the tea until the Red Cross packages get through again. I scrounged this from Sedgwick.
Is he here too?
(laughs } All the "rotten" eggs as Von Luger called us. (beat) They've cleaned out ali the camps and cumped us here. Bartlett stares at him suddenly alert. Ramsey is concerne a What's the matter?
(after pause) What about Tommy Bristol?
No. He's not here yet. But there's an American called Hendley. He's supposed to be twice as good a thief and blackmailer as... (beat) Vhy?
Don't you see? Unknowingly the goons have put together the finest escape team in history. (CONTINUED)

They know what they're doing, Cyril. Have you seen the double wires? The towers? Triple guards? Tunnelling's out - the soil‘s too sandy. They've thought of everything. They've even Strachwitz in charge of the ferrets.
Isaw him. He's very efficient. (beat) I'm calling a meeting of "x" immediately.
(thoughtfully) I think you should stay out of it, Cyril. You're a marked man.
I was elected "Big X". It's my job.
I mow. And you're the best shat's ever been. But I think it's time for a change.
(beat) Do you think I'm wire happy?
I think it would be a good thing for you to slack off. There's plenty of time.

Not for me. (pause) I've an idea that the whole bloody Reich is going to regret the day they built this camp. RAMSEY . I must point out, Cyril, that however unsatisfactory this camp is - or will be - we are still in the hands of the Luftwaffe - not the Gestapo. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
(crisply) The "X" organization was formed to assist escapes - by team effort - not to wage @ private war.
I want to fight the war, sir. The way I know best. I'm not wire happy. Yet. When I am, I'll tell you. You can trust me, sir. A long vause,
All right.

. This, time, you first. Fushes him upward, slaps him on the rump.

starts. Curses. A Single oil lamp flickers,

paces up and down, glances at his watch repeatedly.

watches as he holds the rope's end. He tugs it. A man comes out. Another tug. Griffiths comes out of the hole, starts to run toward the woods. He trips and falls flat on his face, making a thudding noise.
turn and look off'in the direction of the woods. Another guard appears. The three move closer as they talk. One sentry points up toward the woods. They stand listening.

lying prone, not stirring a muscle...

as they listen. Then the sentry who heard the noise in the first place starts off toward the woods to investigat holding his burp gun at ready.

takes as much cover as he dares without lioving. He watches wide-eyed as the German approaches.

moves cautiously to the edge of the woods, looks ail about him tut doesn't see Hilts in the shadows. He turns slowly and starts back towards the fence. New Griffichs is between him and the lights of the comround. He takes a couple of steps toward the compound, then stops, gasps.
silhouetted against the lights of the compound in the backgroun?
as his eyes widen. He approaches Griffiths cautiously, then seeing clearly who he is, raises, his gun to firing position. :

Don't shoot! Den't shoot!
standing over Griffiths, whirls startled, covers Hilts. Behind him, Griffiths jumps up.

Don't shoot! I give up. Don't shoot! The German sentry whirls back toward Griffiths. Cavendish head pors up out of the whole. The German, appalled, shou inarticuiately. Sorren, Haynes and the stocge are at the window - all frozen.

pour out of the guarchouse, hare for the searchlight that has zeroed in on Griffiths who stands paralyzed, his arms above his head. Gutteral shouts. A few isolated shots.
RAMSEY ; : 53° reacts to the continuing short bursts of firing. very tired. Very concerned. He gets up, grimly erect. Begins to exit. . . .
ducks back into the tunnel. Desperate whisper:
Jig's up - the bloody goons... He stares up petrified, as the sentry appears in the hole stares cown at them, menaces them with his burp gun.
(shouting) 'Raus! 'Raus! SOFORT! He fires. a short warning burst into the earth. Cavendish and the others pour up the ladder. Very fast. Some crouch back into the tunnel, petrified.

Bastards. They've knorm all along. They're plugging the blckes as they've been coming out.
Rot! We'd have heard shots before. The goons've just found the hole.
Let's get the hell out of here. He dive= for the trolley and starts paddling back.
An escavee starts back up the shaft to the washroom. One man is at the mouth of the tunnel shouting.
Come. back: Come back! Everyone back! They've found “Harry”! . He starts to pull at the trolley rope.
An escapee on the trolley moving back to the start of the tunnel. He scrambles off and pushes as close to the ladder as he can.
(to the others) Someone's been shot back there. Hurry. I.think the goons are coming down the tunnel. There was someone just behind me.
Second escapee crawls out of the tunnel and shoves toward the shaft,
Hurry up! The goons are coming. I heard one just behind me.
is coming out of the washrcom into the corridor. The block seems to be on fire. Sorren comes toward him through the smoke.

They're burning the papers.
I heard some of the boys were shot. By goons coming through the tunnei. I'm getting the hell out of here} Goff runs out. One or two escapees run after him.
come tearing out the door, the searchlights pick them ur. Machine guns start to chatter. They run back througn the door. INT. HUT 104 - NIGHT . cLOSs 547 as they come running back into the hut.
Change your mind?
Wouldn't you? Geff laughs but stops as the door bursts open and Strachwicc enters. He is carrying a pistol in his hand. Goes.tc the tunnel mouth, looks down.
is nose-to-nose with Griffiths at the front gate. Von Luger's collar is unbuttoned and he has a pistol in his hands. At his side is Posen with a great coat over his pajamas.
(CONTINUED)

Behind them, armed guards: in formation doudle-time from the guardhouse through the inner gate into the compound. A group heads into the forest - sporadic gun fire, gutter commands. Von Luger is literally foaming.

So, you don't want to stay in this camp, eh! COOLER: (shouts at a guard - in German) Get ‘em all into appell? I ONCE. Von Luge~ turns away and hurries toward the compound. Posen shzkes his head angrily, a stream of German...
POU'S stream out to find the hut completely ringed by helmeted armed guards.
Out. Out. Everyone out. Ausgahan. Schnell. Each prisoner is made to strip to his underwear as he comes out of the hut. Strachwitz and the goons are rough with those who resist. . . .

struggles to keep his pants. Von Luger enters ani points to Goff. Govier! VON LUGER ooler? Two armed guards march Goff off as the goons start chivvy the other prisoners into three ranks as Von Luger watches
It's too cold to stand here like this + what sort of nonsense are you up to? Von Luger points to him.
Cooler, Two guards march this prisoner after Goff. As they do - (CONTINUED)
Coo, we are in a pet, aren't we? Von Luger points to him.
Cooler. Two guards march this one away, too. Von Luger draws his »xistol.
If there are any more disturbances I will personally shoot two of you. The ranics of prisoners quiet down, their eyes on Von Lug The whole camp is being shoved into appell...
joins the lineup. He sees Sorren.
(whispers ) How many got ‘out?
(whaspers’) - Don't know exactly, sir. Maybe forty.
shaking with rage, dangerous, walks along the ranks of men...

You're going to stand there till we find out who's missing. If it takes ten hours! Do you understand? If it takes ten days! Is that clear? If it takes ten years! Do I make myself plain? He comes face to face with Ramsey. A moment, then with @ great effort, Von Luger controls himself.

with the other ferrets has not quite completed herding all of the prisoners into line. They are still stalling for time, milling about, pretending confusion. Strachwitz grabs a burp gun from a guard, lays a long burst of pullets just over the heads of a group of the men. Silenc Immediate order as Strachwitz jars in a new clip.
Answer to your names, Adams? Adams?... Arlen. Arlen.
Here.
Baleen? Baleen?... Bartlett. Bartlett?...
as lights go on in building, phones are seen being answerec. Headlights of cars and motorcycles glare as they turn out of entry ways, roar off down deserted streets.

is still at appell. Surrounded by helmeted Wehrmacht Guards. Ramsey in front. Von Luger in front of him. The last of the POW's goes through a team of men who have been making a photo-check, wearily joins. the main body of POW's. The senior non-com tallies a slip of paper, gives it to Strachwitz, an SS man takes the slip arrogantly, looks at it, hands it back - stalks towards main gate. Impassive, Strachwitz glances at the slip, takes it to Posen. Posen glances at it, gives it to Von Luger.
is erect, motionless. But his face is grey and his eyes ved-rimmed. He reads the slip. His face sags.
(barely audible) Sechs und siebensig?
including Sorren. Whicpers:

How many? How many got away? Over fifty? I couldn't hear. I was the last. I saw the figures! Well come on for God's sake! Seventy six! The number is taken up, whispered with the whine of the wind. Exultance = waves of excitement - but held down.
listens. He hears the number. His face doesn't change. He stares at Von Luger who is looking at him cully.
(clears throat) Dismiss!
(turns - a command) Dismiss!
salutes, Ramsey returns it, then the POW's break and collect into little groups. Growing roars of success...
and Germans march grimly out of the compound.

grinds into life. The room is German middle-class. decor. The only light is the cold gray dawn seeping through a curtained window. A man-comes through a doorway leading to a becroom, tying his robe belt. His face is puffy with sleep and his hair is missed. As he passes 2 shaft of light - KUEN!

(picks up receiver) Ja?... Stalag Luft?... Und?... Und? Wieviel? (his voice tightens) Sechs und siebensig?... Unglaublich... Ja... Ja... Gewiss. He slams down the receiver, hurries back to the bedroom.

Lines of helmeted soldiers in full field packs, comb the undergrowth. A distant burst of machine gun fire. CAMERA MOVES to reveal Danny and Willie hiding. They sneak deeper and deeper into the foliage. In the middle distanc a guard starts running - a dim figure fleeing ahead. Burst of machine gun:
(faintly) Don't shoot - Nich Shiessen! I give up... Oh Christ, Johnny's caught it! The guards grab the dim figure, hurry him into the open. In a moment other guards carry out a badly wounded POW.
hare away. All around there are grim searchers. Dogs bay on the wind.
halt traffic on a main road. Military convoys: - civilian trucks. Beginning of a pile up. The main artery slows to a.crawl - each vehicle is searches.

come down a@ small side road that approaches the station. There is a sprinkling of people on the station platform, pacing about as they wait for the train to arrive. Hendley goides Blythe towards the station waiting room, nto it. *

looks about the room aghast. Two-thirds of the people are escapees., all sitting nervously, studiously ignoring each other. Among them are Bartlett, MacDonald, Merivale, and Ashley-Pitt who glances absentiy at the new arrivals as do others in the room.including the real Germans. Hendley leads Blythe out again.
pulls Blythe back against the wall of the builcing.
Trouble?

(whispers) The place is loaded with our guys. I guess everybody's missed their connections and get jammed up here. I think we- He looks eff. A police car is coming down the road. It is moving vast and blasts its siren-horn to clear the way around a truck. Hurriedly Hendley takes Blythe and they duck into a doorway.

react to the dying siren. The police car is heard stoppin outside. A moment, then the door bursts open and two police officers come in, look about the room. The escapees almost jump out of their skins as they attempt bland interest. The first policeman spots what he is looking for - a telphone - and heads for it. Getting his ‘ number he rattles off a long string of German. This cau @ murmur of excitement among the real Germans in the room A woman sitting next to Merivale turns and speaks to him in German. He nods enthusiastically - not understanding a word she says. As the woman turns back to listen to the policeman on the phone once more, Merivale turns to Ashle Pitt who is sitting next to him, stares at him questionin ly. During this, the policeman waiting at the door, becom ing aware cf Merivale and Ashley-Pitt, regards them . suspiciously. The first policeman hangs up the phone an heads for the door, ealls briskly for his associate to follow. Escapees breathe inaudible sighs of relief.
The whistle of an approaching train.
Where do we buy tickets?
On the train. Taking Blythe's arm, he guides him into position.

make their way along the platform as the train pulls in. The piatform crowds - civilians of all types, foreign workers, military personnel. The other escapees spread themselves as the train stops. Passengers descend. Others board. Bartlett and MacDonald move through the crowd looking for a compartment.
get aboard a coach near the end of the train as do some others of the escapees.
approach a forward car which has compartments that open to the outside. Bartlett, opens the door of ohe which seems empty, for MacDonald, who gets in quickly, freezes.

are side by side on the long seat. Two are dozing. One is reading a manual. The other “is cleaning his néils. The one cleaning his nails glances idly at MacDonald. STATION MASTER'S VOICE. Einsteigen. Somewhere 2 whistle blows.
stands in the aisle, paralyzed. Bartlett looks down at the feet of one of the dozing SS officers, glares at him and clears his throat loudly.
who is cleaning his nails, nudges the sleeper who awakens sits up, puts his feet down.
Entschuldigen Sie.
‘O

stow their luggage and overcoats and sit down, the SS officer reading the manual lights a cigar, looks Bartlett gad MacDonald over with casual interest. Bartlett takes a folded Paris newspaper, LeSoir, out of his pocket, whips it open, gives MacDonald half, starts to read. The train starts to move.
sit near the rear of the car. As the train gains speed Hendley looks back through the window...
Two pelice cars pull up at the station. Pelice pile out of the cavs, hurry into the station building.
Exhales, leans back in his seat, studies the other occupants of the sparsely filled car. The seats immediate around Hendley and Biythe are empty.

THE TRAIN . se 580 passes by - rattles across the bridge. that passes over @ small river. ‘On the road paralleling the tracks, Danny and Willie. trudge along. The sound of approaching motors emerges from. the diminishing sound of the train. Danny and Willie run off the road.

Danny and Willie come down the embankment, hide under the arch of the bridge as a dozen military motorcycles zoom by overhead. The last of these have sidecars carrying praca men. Danny glances off, reacts, runs off. Willie ollows,

The road is narrow and winds through a thick forest. Hilt comes up out of a deep ravine. Standing at the edge of th road, he studies its relation to the ravine. Makes some mental calculations, then takes the piano wire from his pocket (now tied together in one long ‘single length) anc crossing the road, ties one end of it to a tree. ( CONTINUED)

He lays the wire sleck across the road on a bias to the edge of the ravine. Picking up a heavy branch, he ties the end of the wire to the top end of the branch. The sound of approaching motors. Hilts grabs the branch, runs back to the cover of the trees beyond the ravine. Places thc branch as a lever ard braces himself.

that pavsed Danny and Willie, comes roaring around the corner in single file, stretched out now by the winding road. One by one the motorcycles zoom across the slack wire on the road. Between the last and the next to last, Hilts hauls the wire taut. The motorcycle (with sidecar) caroms along the slanting wire and is deflected into the ravine. It disappears from sight, a thump is heard, then silence, except for the sound of the departing motorcycle

are sprawled in the ravine - out cold. Ignoring them, Hilts goes directly to the motorcycle, goes over it to see if it is seriously damaged. Almost tenderly, as if it were a friend who had taken a fall. Finally satisfied, he turns his attention to the inert Germans. Tries one of the helmets on. Too big. Tries the other. It's okay. EXT. RIVERS EDGE = DAY . A TINY ROWBOAT ‘ 585 bebs in the water. Danny and Willie rush down, Danny Picks up the oars. Willie unties and shoves off.
as Hilts wheels his motorcycle out of the ravine, climbs aboard. The outfit he has put together from the two Germa doesn't look too ill-fitting.
starts the machine. Roars off.
as Hilts barrels flat out into the turn, loses it, and flies across a ditch and plasters the motorcycle and himself onto a field.
as Hilts hops around the fields in pain, hanging on te hi leg. He stops, looks at the motorcycle reproachfully.
comes to a stop. On the platform amongst the travelers are three policemen accompanied by two armed members of the Wehrmacht. The search begins. First the outside compartments.
react. The door opens and a Policeman enters. He barely glances at the identity cards offered by the SS officers. He studies Bartlett and MacDonald's papers carefully.
Frankreich?
Oui.
Moi aussi. The official hands back their papers.
(moving on) Sehr gut;
Hendley, Blythe, Merivale, Ashley-Pitt and the others wai - nervous - uncertain what is happening.
signals the engineer to proceed and then climbs aboard th train as it pulls out.
AS the train picks up speed, Hendley leaves his seat, murmurs to Blythe:
Think I'd better see what's going on. (CONTINUED )
He moves through the doors into the coach ahead. .
wait tensely. In a moment Hendley reenters the coach, tap Blythe and leads the way back in the coach. As he passes Ashley-Pitt he whispers:
Tallyho! Ashley-Pitt grimly decides to brazen it out, sits back firmly. As he does so, Merivale gets up, goes into the W.C. and closes the door,
come out.
Colin, we'd never make the interrogation going on up there. He moves Blythe to the lower step on the side of the car. Blythe squints at the rugged and precipitous countryside going by fast.
Are we “going to jump?
I'll tap you when.
I'd prefer it if you'd simply give me a sound push, old chap. A reasonably smooth section of the embankment comes into view. Hendley gives Blythe a heave. Jumps off after him.

text: 4 hit the embankment. Half running, half falling, they fly down the sloping embankment of the tracks to a crash stop at the foot of some trees. As the train goes out of sight Hendley picks himself up, goes to Blythe.
All right? (CONTINUED)

Blythe nods "yes" but inéicates with a gesture his breath is knocked ovt. His glasses are still on his nose - the glass shattered. His fingers tell him his ciothes are badly tern. Hendley goes over his own ripped and stained clothes. HENDLEY (continuing) (disgusted) First we can't handle the language. Now the papers you sweated over won't do us any good. I've really loused this up.
(getting his breath) Now what?
(sits down) I den't know. Let me think.

The train is slowing down now as it swings into the turns cf a steep grade. The police are completing their ex- amination of ‘the passengers. One of them goes’ to the he of the car followed by the two soldiers as the other finishes his scrutiny of Ashley-Pitt's papers.
(handing them back) Sehr gut.
Danke. - The first policeman notices the W.C., knocks, then tries the door. It ts locked.
(curtly) Ausmachen! Polizer! Sofort!
reacts. He looks about the tiny compartment anxiously, sees a small hatch-type air vent in the roof above it.

raps angrily on the door, tells the conductor to unlock the door. The door crashes open. The W.C. is empty. The policeman looks about the little room astonished. The conductor snaps the handle of the door back and forth, ventures the opinion it wasn't locked - only stuck. The policemun accepts this, moves on.

lies flat on top of the train. He stares ahead - gasps. The front part of the train is entering a tunnel - a smal storne-faced oval which makes a tight fit for the train. He:-watches the tunnel approach and as the car he is on goes into it, the screen becomes obscured and then black with the boiling smoke from the engine. After a few seconds, the train emerges from the tunnel into the sun light again and the smcke dissipates. Merivale is gone!

as. the smoke left by the train swirls clear we see Meriv hanging by his hands from the wooden cross members that hold signal wires at the top of the tunnel. He drops to the tracks, observes his bruised. hands then takes off up the cinders. “EXT. ROAD - HILL COUNTRY - DAY
is moving along sedately on his motorcycle. Seeing some- thing ahead, he eases back on the throttle.
Many vehicles are lined up in both directions as police Search ‘them, examine the papers of the irritated occupan
looks about for some way to avoid this. There is none. Assuming a nonchalant air, he proceeds.
Slows his motorcycle toa bare crawl and politely and casually weaves it between the closely parked double row of vehicles. As he squeezes his way by the examining Gestapo men and police. (CONTINUED )
Heil Hitler! The man reacts mechanically. Hilts continues slowly until clear of the vehicles, then picks up speed.
smiles, pleased with himself.
A wide sweep of the broad river past a towering castle. In the middle, the tiny rowboat is going down stream. And not far behind it, the tributary it left.
is rowing, Willie fishes happily from the stern.
and two other escapees race through the woods in a desper mun. Behind them, the baying of dogs...
fight their way through “the undergrowth, Slip, half fall get up, race on...
charge in pursuit. Twenty or thirty soldiers lope along, burp guns ready. One sees something ahead, Stops, fires a burst.

find themselves boxed in. No escape now. Desperately they begin to fan out, toss their documents away, compass etc. One shins up a tree, another darts for a bush, gets under, Sedgwick desperately tries to scale the rockface o the ravine...
burst out into the open. A soldier reacts, fires a burst of bullets...
freezes as the bullets spray around him. Miraculously he is unhurt. .
as all the escapees are herded together. Roughly.

has a tug with a string of barges stopped. Police search. The beginning of a foul-up in the river - the barges get tangled. Curses. In the distance, another patrol boat scurries after a freighter. In the far distance the tiny rowboat heads down stream.
cars . 618 full of SS men take off to join the search.
hurry out - in column - or in trucks to join the search. EXT, HUGE STATION - Day -
There is a monumental foul-up as police and SS men block trains, check passes. Lines of patient - and impatient - civilians. .

Roads go in several directions. Maze of signs including temporary military markers using code deSignations as wel as norm.l place and distance route signs. A police car, half hicden, is parked nearby.
pulls to a stop, studies the signs - all of which are unintelligible to him. Decides on a route, takes off.
watch as Hilts leaves.
is again confronted with a forest of signs. Makes another blind choice, turns to the left.
One of the policemen gets the other's attention, points.

has made a circle, comes back to the same intersection he has just left, stops, confused. Behind him the police car pulls out, starts toward him. Seeing them, Hilts takes off again. The police car SOUNDS its siren. Hiits opens the threttle. .

as Hilts loses the police car, broadsiding the motorcycle and sidecar around sharp turns and into narrow side stree Finally gets a road out of town, loses the chasing police car. Temporarily. EXT. ROAD - Day MERIVALE a . 628 marches along at a good clip. He steps ‘aside as a good quality car passes, stops. A moment's indecision, then Merivale brightens as he realizes the driver 4s offering him a ride. .
Strings of barges and other river traffic work up river. The little rowboat goes by them on its way down river. Danny's head is bent as he bends to the oars in a steady long stroke.
Spell you for a turn. Danny shakes his head. Then stops rowing momentarily, looking baci.
(a warning) Willie! (CONTINUED)
Willie looks bac, takes out a pipe, lights it, and holds the fishing line:
overhauls the rowboat.
holds up a string of fish, waves | the patrol boat away w an irritated gesture which says “don't scare away the "fish". The launch veers off and speeds away.
Amazing the courtesy one fisherman shows another. (reacts to string of fish) Danny, can't I chuck 'em overboard - they're getting dreadfully ripe.
When you catch some more! Vaillie puts the fish back down in the bottom of the boat Turns his head to the wind. . EXT. ROAD _- OPEW COUNTRY - DAY - .

The road rises sharply and drops off sharply as it turns. Hilts comes tearing over the rise in the motorcycle and sidecar, climbs the hill, goes down the other side where he turns off the road suddenly and disappears into the trees, where he is completely hidden. The German police car hurtles in pursuit, bounces up and down the hill and almost turns over on the turn at the bottom of the hill.
watches the departing car. Thinks for a moment. Nods his head. Then begins to unhook the sidecar.
and MacDonald stretch tirediy. Bartlett nods to MacDonald who goes to sleep. Now the compartment is crowded. Blinds down for blackout. A few sleepy passengers watch him curiously.
sits on his: suitcase in the jammed corridors, grimly tries to sleep. Beyond him, cther escapees try to make themselves inconspicuous. The train begins to slow. Another station.
